title: Slow AI Live: Why Pedagogy Should Replace Policing
subtitle: Watch now | A poem, a provocation, and a prompt about replacing surveillance with dialogue in the classroom.
author: Dr Sam Illingworth
content_html:
Thank you , , , , , and many others for tuning into the first Slow AI live of 2026.

Slow AI is a shared space for reflection. All posts are free, but if you wish to support the work, you can choose a paid subscription.

The current educational response to AI is often a game of deception. This session used a poem by Howard Nemerov to explore the absurdity of rote learning and the ‘invisible things’ we ask students to master. When we try to trick students into admitting AI use, we prioritise ‘catching’ over ‘teaching’. This shift undermines the trust required for genuine inquiry. We explored how to replace the arms race of detection with the friction of conversation. One poem, one provocation, one prompt, to slow down and replace the arms race of detection with the friction of conversation.

Poem

To David, About His Education

By Howard Nemerov

Provocation

Education is becoming a theatre of mutual suspicion. When educators set ‘AI traps’ or use unreliable detection software, they treat learning as a contest of wit rather than a development of mind. Nemerov’s poem mocks the invisible things’ that adults force children to learn. Today, these invisible things are the opaque algorithms of detection tools.

Treating AI as a secret to be exposed forces students to become better liars. It encourages them to hide their process.

If we want students to use AI responsibly, we must make the invisible visible.

This requires dialogue.

We must ask students why they made specific choices rather than demanding they prove their innocence.

Surveillance is a failure of pedagogy.

Education should be about dialogue, not punishment.

Prompt

Try this prompt with an AI tool of your choice. It is deigned to turn the AI into a Socratic partner, creating the friction necessary to reveal how a student or educator actually thinks.

I want to explore [insert topic]. Act as a Socratic Coach. Do not provide a summary or an answer. Instead, ask me one question at a time to help me uncover the ‘invisible’ gaps in my own understanding. Stop after each question to let me respond.

In the live, I used an abridged version because spoken prompts need to be memorable and repeatable.

I want to explore [insert topic]. Don’t give me answers. Ask one question at a time to help me find the gaps in my thinking.

If you find yourself searching for ways to trick your students, stop. Ask what that impulse says about the value of the task you have set. If a task can be solved by a tool without a student needing to think, the task is the problem.

Focus on the dialogue.

Focus on the learning that happens when two humans talk.

Support Slow AI

I’m developing an alternative to AI detection software. This tool focuses on human agency and the learning process rather than surveillance. I’m seeking educators and students to beta test this approach and provide critical feedback. Please drop me a DM if you want to participate in refining a pedagogy-first solution.

Go Slow
